title: Mum told she's 'too fat' to have baby loses half her body weight to make dream come true
text:

Weight had not been an issue for Tasha Frampton throughout her teen years.

She’d always considered herself to be an ‘average’ size.

But in her mid-20s, she started to pile on the pounds.

‘It happened when I was newly married.

'I was happy and I wasn’t being careful about what I ate,’ says Tasha, who works in payroll.

Before she knew it, as she approached 30, she was a size 22 and weighed 19 stone.

But there was another reason Tasha had turned to food.

‘Some of it was comfort eating, because about a year after getting married, my husband Ross and I started trying for a baby and it just didn’t happen.

‘I have lots of dreams, but the main one was starting a family.

'I’m the eldest of four and had a lovely childhood.

‘We were trying for about five years and thought it was never going to happen.

'We had all sorts of tests, but doctors couldn’t ever find a medical reason why I couldn’t get pregnant.’

Tasha had tried losing weight in the past, but she didn’t think size was an issue when it came to having a baby.

‘Friends my size had had little ones, so why shouldn’t I?

I didn’t see why my weight was such a problem.’

Eventually, after almost giving up hope on having the family they craved, Tasha and Ross decided to try IVF.

But Tasha was in for a shock when doctors told her she needed to lose weight.

‘They said I had to reduce my BMI to 30 before we could even begin IVF, because if I didn’t, it was far less likely to work.’

The news hit home with Tasha.

‘I’d tried diets before but nothing had worked.

'However, this time I was so determined and totally focused.

'I badly needed to change my eating habits.’

Tasha would often skip breakfast – but then have a packet of crisps when she got to work.

‘For lunch I’d go to the supermarket and buy a pasty or a triple sandwich with white bread and cheese and mayonnaise, which I’d have with a fizzy or sugary fruit drink.

‘I’d probably have a couple of snacks in the afternoon, perhaps another bag of crisps – I love crisps – and a bar of chocolate and more unhealthy drinks.’

Tea would involve ridiculously portioned meals – ‘My husband has always been able to eat what he wants and stay slim’ – like a bowl of nachos each, with loads of cheese and a bowl of chilli with spoonfuls of soured cream, cheese and pitta bread.

‘Then I’d probably have another bag of crisps and a bar of chocolate or sweets.’

Reaching her goal

Tasha managed to lose a couple of stone on her own by calorie counting and going to the gym, before she realised she needed help.

She chose The Jane Plan, which creates healthy meals that are delivered to the client.

‘I wanted something regimented and strict that I didn’t have to think about,’ says Tasha.

‘Something that I didn’t have to have control over, just add veg if I wanted and pop it in the microwave.’

Breakfast was usually something like a healthy muesli or porridge, lunch was soup or a tuna or salmon fillet with bulgur wheat, and dinner might be chicken in a low-calorie sauce that Tasha could add veg to, or a pasta dish.

‘I really enjoyed the food, so it didn’t seem like a diet.

'It was tasty and good for me, and as well as helping me to lose weight, it got me back on track with healthy eating and appropriate portion sizes.’

It took just over a year, but Tasha lost almost half her body weight, reaching 10 stone, a healthy weight for her frame.

She’d also gone from a size 22 to a size 10.

Exciting news

Losing weight meant Tasha and Ross could finally start IVF.

It was gruelling, but all her hard work wasn’t for nothing.

After their first cycle of treatment, the day had finally arrived to find out if it had worked.

‘We’d been told to do the test on a specific date and this was it.

'I really needed to go for a wee, so I woke my husband and told him I was going to do it.

‘We waited together, looking at the stick for the result to come up in the little window.

'Finding out I was pregnant was overwhelming and amazing – I was over the moon.

'We just hugged each other, it was really emotional.

‘Losing weight was good – I felt good.

'But the best reward of all was to fall pregnant.

'I couldn’t believe it at first.’

Family first

Baby Arabelle was born on 3 December 2015 and was an energetic bundle of joy.

‘She’s beautiful and so lively and active – she really keeps me on my toes,’ says Tasha.

‘She has made motherhood everything I wanted and thought it would be.

'It’s just absolutely wonderful.’

But neither Tasha nor Ross wanted her to be an only child.

‘I had a great childhood growing up with my siblings,’ says Tasha, ‘so I wanted that for Arabelle.

'We decided to use one of the frozen embryos left from treatment.

'And it worked again.’

Now Arabelle is three years old, and Tasha is pregnant with her second child, due in November.

Tasha says, ‘I’m finally going to have the family I always wanted, which, if I’m honest, I was frightened I’d never have.

‘To have one child was amazing – but to have two children will make us complete and fulfil my dreams.

'I am so happy.

‘It’s hard to believe, having thought I might never get pregnant, that our little girl is going to have a brother or sister.

‘I think this will be it, but who knows?!

'What I do know is that having this family means the world to me.

'The most important thing in life is to be happy – and I am, and I’ll do everything to make sure my children are just as happy too.

‘Losing weight has helped me achieve my dreams, and that means every ounce, every pound, every stone was worth it.

'A family is worth its weight in gold.

‘All I had ever dreamed of was having a family and being a mum, so Arabelle means everything to me and Ross, just like our other child will when he or she comes along.

‘In losing weight I have gained so much – I have gained everything I ever wanted.’
description: Tasha Frampton, 36, from Farnborough, was told she needed to dramatically lose weight, or lose her dream of getting pregnant
